tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry|Poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism|Parallelism]])

tn.ref: he is robed in majesty; Yahweh has clothed and girded himself with strength
tn.text: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh's strength and majesty as if they were things Yahweh wears. AT: "he shows everyone that he is a powerful king" or "his majesty is there for all to see, like the robe a king wears; everything about Yahweh shows that he is strong and he is ready to do great work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile|Simile]])
the power of a king and the way a king acts
put on a belt—a band of leather or another material that a person wears around his waist—to prepare for work or battle
This can be stated in active form. AT: "You have firmly established the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "no one will ever move it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

tn.ref: Your throne is established from ancient times
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "You established your throne in ancient times" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

Some versions read "floods ... floods'." The word often refers to a river (see "the River," [[:en:bible:notes:psa:072:008|72:8]]), but "oceans ... oceans'" has been chosen here because oceans, not rivers, have "waves" that "crash and roar."

tn.ref: have lifted up their voice; the oceans' waves crash and roar
tn.text: The psalmist speaks of the ocean as if it were a person who could speak. AT: "have made a mighty noise because their waves crash and roar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Above the crashing of many waves, the mighty breakers of the sea
tn.text: The phrase "the mighty breakers of the sea" means basically the same thing as "many waves" and emphasizes how great these waves are. AT: "Above the crashing of all of the very great waves of the sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The psalmist speaks of where God lives as if it were high above the earth. AT: "in heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The psalmist speaks of Yahweh's house as if it were a woman wearing beautiful clothing or jewelry and of Yahweh's holiness as the beautiful clothing or jewelry. AT: "your house is beautiful because you are holy" or "your holiness makes your house beautiful the way beautiful clothes and jewelry make a woman more beautiful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
